title: Royals who 'broke the rules' on their wedding day

Weddings are often traditional affairs, perhaps none more so than for the British Royal Family.

The Windsors are nothing if not sticklers for official protocol but that hasn't stopped various royal brides and grooms going their own way now and again.

For example, women tying the knot usually borrow tiaras from the Queen's vault for their big day.

But a few brides have broken this tradition and have chosen for their own headpieces, including Princess Diana when she married Charles in 1981.

Here are some other royal traditions that have been smashed by newlyweds.

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle

(Image: Getty Images)

The American actress married Diana's second son at St George's Chapel in Windsor Castle on May 19, last year.

Unlike his grandfather Prince Phillip and brother William, the Duke of Sussex decided to wear a wedding ring when he married Meghan.

Harry further broke with tradition after selecting a platinum wedding ring rather the usual Welsh gold that has been selected in the past.

Meghan - owing to her family situation - also walked herself down the aisle at, something unheard of at previous weddings.

Diana Spencer and Prince Charles

(Image: Tim Graham/Getty Images)

Charles and Lady Di tied the knot on July 29, 1981 at St Paul's Cathedral.

It was the first time a Prince of Wales had married in more than 100 years, and attracted a huge television audience from around the world.

In many ways it was the most traditional royal wedding you can imagine - except for one word.

Diana started a new tradition of her own when she chose to remove 'obey' in her marriage vows.

Some 30 years later Kate Middleton chose to do exactly the same thing when she married Diana's eldest son.

Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank

(Image: Getty Images)

The couple's wedding had one major change from protocol when Princess Beatrice became the maid of honour for the occasion - an unusual role for a royal of her status.

Beatrice is technically ahead of her sister in the line of succession and this would typically prevent her from taking up the such an honour.

Such a long-standing rule prevented Kate from being Pippa Middleton's maid of honour in 2017 but an exception was made in the case of Beatrice due to the pair's similar rank.

(Image: Getty Images Europe)

Kate Middleton and Prince William

The future King and Queen of England got hitched at Westminster Abbey on April 29, 2011.

Millions tuned in live to watch the monumental day eight years ago but it differed from other memorable royal weddings in one way.

Most royal brides are whisked way on their honeymoon the day of their wedding.

For example, the Queen and Prince Phillip spent their wedding night in Broadlands, Hampshire.

But Prince William and Kate instead spent the night in Buckingham Place and only embarked on their honeymoon to the Seychelles ten days later.
description: Royal weddings are usually highly traditional affairs but some royal couples have broken rank with generations-old conventions
